items.title: Der Vogel
items.content_html:
Vorgestern bin ich im Biergarten der Alten Messe zum Mittag. Der Biergarten ist nahezu leergefegt; die Mittagszeit ist eigentlich schon vorbei.

An der Ausgabe entscheide ich mich f√ºr Bratwurst mit Sauerkraut. Gro√üer Teller, gro√üe Wurst, gro√üe Portion Sauerkraut. Lecker! Fix bezahlt und einen Tisch gesucht. Ein paar Meter weiter sitzt ein √§lterer Herr √ºber einen Masskrug gebeugt; mit einem kurzen Nicken best√§tigen wir uns gegenseitig unsere Existenz zu dieser Stunde, an diesem Ort.

Ich setze mich, reisse mein Senft√ºtchen auf‚Äîund muss feststellen, dass ich versehentlich Mayonnaise1 gegriffen habe. Mon dieu! Entschlossen stehe ich auf, gehe zur Ausgabe, nehme mir ein Senft√ºtchen, drehe mich um‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶und sehe einen Raben auf meinem Teller sitzen.

Kurz nachgedacht: Nein, ich kann mich nicht entsinnen, den gekauft zu haben. Was geht da vor?!

Ich mache einen Schritt auf meinen Tisch zu. Zehn Meter trennen mich von meinem Ziel.

Der Rabe schaut mich an. Ich schaue den Raben an.

[Tumbleweed fliegt durchs Bild.]

Seine kleinen schwarzen Knopfaugen mustern mich.

Ich mache noch einen Schritt.

Der Rabe greift meine Wurst mit dem Schnabel und fliegt davon.

‚Ä¶

WAS. ZUM. TEUFEL.

Ich bin dann zu meinem Tisch gegangen, hab die Fu√üspuren in meinem Sauerkraut begutachtet, mich auf- und danach wieder abgeregt, hab die Dame an der Kasse danach gefragt, wo ich den Rest meines Essens entsorgen kann, und ihr auf Nachfrage die letzten vier Minuten meines Lebens kurz zusammengefasst. Als ich auf ihr “Ja, wollen’s a naie Portion?” hin antwortete, dass mein Budget f√ºr die Pause aufgebraucht sei, √ºberlegte sie kurz, und gab mir trotzdem einen neuen Teller, aufs Haus. Das nenn ich mal Dienst am Kunden! Daf√ºr gibts zwei Pluspunkte.

Ich denke, dies war meine bizarrste Mittagsgeschichte bisher. Verdammtes Rabenviech.

  1. Es wird immer “Mayonnaise” heissen. Der Tag, an dem ich die sog. “neue Schreibweise” benutze, wird der Tag sein, an dem das Abendland untergeht. ↩︎

items.title: Still Running: First Continuous 5km
items.content_html:
I ran my first continuous 5km today. My workouts are 5km+ already, but usually I follow a run-walk-run-walk-run routine (2km running, 500m walking, repeat).

This morning I just didn‚Äôt stop running until I was back home again, 25 minutes later, which means my ‚Äújust keep going‚Äù pace is ~4:50 min/km.

Damn, I am proud of myself. Harr!

items.title: Still Running: April 2008
items.content_html:
Yes, I am still running. I‚Äôve gone through a whole month of running three or four times a week, had some ups and downs, but didn‚Äôt quit. Yay, go me. ;) Here‚Äôs my April 2008 diary‚ÄîI want to write it down, because I think that picking up running is one of my bigger achievements in recent years, mostly because it takes so much fricking energy to do it. :p

It still isn‚Äôt fun. At all. Yet I know it‚Äôs good for me and my health and will pay out in the long run (pun intended). Thus, I keep going.

Gear

I fell for the Nike+ system. It rocks. (See below.) Plus I got better shoes‚ÄîNike Air Zoom Structure Triax+. Comfy, light, I really like them.

Also, I bought some simple and light pants for running an a similarly simple ‚Äúsoft-shell‚Äù jacket. Makes a bit of a difference, as they keep me cooler than a pair of jeans and a sweatshirt.

Nike+

What can I say: I am loving it.

In case you haven‚Äôt heard of it, it‚Äôs a little sensor sitting on or in your shoe, tracking the distance you‚Äôve run or walked and your speed. The counterpart is a little dongle for your iPod nano, storing the data and displaying your progress. It offers several training modes (basic, distance, speed‚Ä¶) and comes with little built-in people who tell you how well you are doing. For example, I tend to run 5km in the morning, and the friendly lass in my iPod will now periodically tell me about my progress. In return, I try to make her like me and keep going.

Also, if you sign up on NikePlus.com, your iPod will sync your progress on the site next time you connect it to your computer. And this is the real kicker‚Äîyou get stats on your runs and overall progress reports, you can check out graphs on your distances and speeds, you can make the site set up training plans, set goals for a month or year, and so on. Hell, if you‚Äôre inclined to do so, you can even create or accept challenges for and from other runners all over the world. Plus you get badges for your website or blog if you feel like sharing. Pretty crazy.

Anyways, what I really like about the Nike+ is: It makes running a game. Before, I was just running. But since I am a geek, I crave for numbers. I want to know my progress, right here, right now. How far into the run am I? Will these 2km I‚Äôve said I‚Äôll run in one go never end? What‚Äôs my pace? Now I have all this information strapped to my upper arm, on the display of my iPod. It‚Äôs great.

And since I know now what I can do, since I have numbers I can work with, since I can see real progress, since I am aware of what I‚Äôve achieved, I now feel much more comfortable with setting goals for myself. My April goal was running 40km alltogether, and I‚Äôve done that. In fact, I‚Äôve done so well that I‚Äôve decided to go for 60km in May. It might not sound like much, but for someone who didn‚Äôt do anything just 2 months ago it‚Äôs okay, I guess.

My overall goal for 2008 is 250km, by the way.

I think without the Nike+, I would‚Äôve quit some time ago. And to give credit where it‚Äôs due, it‚Äôs all Russ Pitts‚Äô fault, really.

Finding Your Pace

This is a big one. Thanks to Podrunner I found out that my perfect running pace seems to be 142 steps per minute. I managed to run 2km in a go more than once. Unfortunately, there aren‚Äôt many constant 142 bpm music mixes available, so now I‚Äôm playing around with a recording of a metronome, the beat sans the music. We‚Äôll see how that‚Äôll work out. The upside is that I might finally end up hearing the birds chirping. ;)

And for the record, my 5km routine is usual split up in 1.5km running, 0.5km walking, 1.5km running, 0.5km walking, 1km running.

NikePlus.com Oddities

Oh yes, NikePlus.com. I have a love/hate relationship with that site. It‚Äôs pretty, but atrocious in some parts. Let me explain.

  • It‚Äôs a full-Flash site. Even the login form is in Flash. Well done, guys. I am so glad my password manager doesn‚Äôt work there, really.
  • The run graphs look different on EU and US site. Specifically, the ‚ÄúUS graphs‚Äù are more detailed than the ‚ÄúEU graphs‚Äù. See this example, which are the two graphs for the exact same run (EU first, US second): Eh.
  • They offer OSX widgets for progress, goals etc.! Great in theory, but these are all broken on Leopard for months by now, with no fix in sight. The users complain, noone really cares. I mean, really, who uses Leopard?!
  • Oh, and did I mention there are different OSX widgets, depending on whether you‚Äôre on an US or EU NikePlus.com site?
  • Also, there are website badges, little Flash doodads for your website or blog. Nice, and they mostly work. The ‚ÄúLast 5 Runs‚Äù HTML badge is only available from the US site, tho. WTF?
  • The site has a ‚ÄúCoach‚Äù section which can be used to set up training plans for you. Again, good in theory, but it seems to have problems w/ custom trainings – my Mon+Wed+Fri routine became Tue+Thu+Sat on reload. Not just once, no – every time.

Here‚Äôs to running!

Shit, I actually seem to like it. How could that happen? Well, at least I have the feeling I am doing something for myself.

I guess there are worse things.

items.title: Twitter Twerp Scan update: Reputation
items.content_html:
Another late night Twerp Scan coding session. I mean, why not? ;) So, what‚Äôs new today?

  • User reputation: You know the people you‚Äôre following, right? If you like what they do, give them a thumbs up or down rating. (No registration necessary. Just click.)
  • Some more pagination options: If you want, you can see all your contacts at once now.
  • The table columns can be re-ordered. Want the verdict right next to the name? Click the column header, hold the mouse button and drag it over.
  • More vertical space. It‚Äôs a wide table, after all.

For me, the reputation is a big one. Up until now, there was no way (that I know of) that allowed for community-driven behaviour rating. Here‚Äôs the idea: we can block the ‚Äúbad guys‚Äù all we want, but if I‚Äôd block @buyinsurancelol, you wouldn‚Äôt know. But now I can give the guy a ‚Äúthumbs down‚Äù in Twerp Scan, and if you have him in your contact list, you will see he‚Äôs got a thumbs down.

On the other hand, if a 100 people think @MyBlogLog is an okay guy (he is) and give his Twerp Scan contact list entry a ‚Äúthumbs up‚Äù, you‚Äôll see it in your contact list (on Twerp Scan)‚Äîwhich might convince you his 1:7 ratio and his following 15k other people are okay.

Well, at least that‚Äôs the idea. It‚Äôs a community-driven experiment. So consider playing around with it for the betterment of interwebs! Since it‚Äôs a pluggable system I think there are other possibilities‚Ä¶ For example a Greasemonkey script that adds the reputation thumbs to the actual Twitter pages etc. Let‚Äôs brainstorm. The comments are open.

Well, that‚Äôs it. Head on over to Twerp Scan to check out the new features. And please let me know what you think, either via Twitter or the comments below.

(By the way, big thanks to the YUI team, the Yahoo! Pipes and JS- Kit for making this endeavour so simple. Appreciate it! Now if there only was something so simple to make the page less fugly‚Ä¶)

Well, at least that‚Äôs the idea. It‚Äôs a community-driven experiment. So consider playing around with it for the betterment of interwebs! Since it‚Äôs a pluggable system I think there are other possibilities‚Ä¶ For example a Greasemonkey script that adds the reputation thumbs to the actual Twitter pages etc. Let‚Äôs brainstorm. The comments are open.

Well, that‚Äôs it. [Head on over to Twerp Scan to check out the new features.][1] And please let me know what you think, either via Twitter or the comments below.

(By the way, big thanks to the [YUI][3] team, the [Yahoo! Pipes][4] and [JS-
Kit][5] for making this endeavour so simple. Appreciate it! Now if there only was something so simple to make the page less fugly‚Ä¶)

items.title: Twitter Twerp Scan update

items.title: Twitter Twerp Scan
items.content_html:
Over the last few days I‚Äôve pursued my idea to build a ‚ÄúTwitter spammer detector‚Äù of sorts using only client-side technologies. I didn‚Äôt feel like setting up server components at all.

What was it supposed to do? It should check the number of followers of everyone on your contact list, the number of people they are following, and the ratio between those. If the person is following more than 1000 people (can be customised), and has a Following-to-Followers ratio higher than 1:1 (can be customised), you‚Äôd be informed (by a handy ‚ÄúBlock‚Äù link).

Thanks to Pipes, the YUI libraries and the Twitter API returning JSON, I was able to finish the first version of Twitter Twerp Scan in a relatively short period of time.

My Javascript-fu is still a bit weak, but getting better. It‚Äôs a nice change to only have one local file to work with (excluding CSS, of course).

Over the weekend, the traffic to that page increased quite a bit, mostly because several people liked the idea enough to link the site.

I’ve set up a Twitter account for service updates etc. – twerpscan. The rest of my tweets will go to Carlo as usual.

items.title: Running: Recap Week One
items.content_html:
I‚Äôm in the running business for a bit over a week so far. I‚Äôve managed to finish the first four runs without breaking down, getting hit by a car, having to cry, falling or getting lost; and without dropping a single run.

I‚Äôm kind of proud of myself.

Using an unnamed maps site, I‚Äôve laid out a nice 4.5km route in the neighbourhood. My first route was only 3.75km, which turned out to be too short. I got home while the music was still playing‚Ä¶ unacceptable. So, back to the drawing board, add a few streets, great.

I still don‚Äôt like it. The second half of each go is nice, tho‚Ä¶ because I know I‚Äôm about to get home.

Nevermind, I‚Äôll keep on doing it. Can‚Äôt hurt, and it makes me feel better.

Unless I break down, get hit by a car, have to cry, fall or get lost, that is.

items.title: Ma.gnolia FAIL, Or: Rendering OpenID Useless
items.content_html:
I can‚Äôt really remember the other few sites where I‚Äôve seen this, but Ma.gnolia‚Äôs newly added OpenID support is a good example on how not to implement OpenID.

So I go there to register an account, and sure enough, I find an OpenID form.

I click the button, allow Ma.gnolia to use my ID, and end up here:

Umm, yeah‚Ä¶ but no. I used my OpenID so I do not have to think about new usernames. I believe that asking me to come up with an unique username completely defies the concept of OpenID. Using OpenID in this form is like having a story line in a porn movie. Sure, you can boast that your movie has a plot, but who cares? It‚Äôs still just a smutty flick.

Somehow I think that one of us two isn‚Äôt completely understanding the concept of OpenID. Is it me?

(Disclaimer: I am not discussing the overall quality of Ma.gnolia here. I don‚Äôt use it. Others do and seem to like it, so I have no opinion in that regard.)

items.title: "I like it!" (It's called Auto Suggestion)
items.content_html:
After much deliberation I‚Äôve decided to give running another shot. No, not the short “omg the bus is leaving!!1” burst-kind of running (I do that rather often), but the type where you excercise three days a week for half an hour or so.

Since I usually don‚Äôt come home before nightfall I will go with the morning routines. But I don‚Äôt want my work day schedule to change, so I‚Äôll just get out of bed ~45 minutes earlier. At least that‚Äôs the plan.

So today I got up at 6:30, brushed my teeth, had a glass of water, got into my clothes, put on the headphones and started running to the music.

Here‚Äôs my setup:

Clothing: I don‚Äôt have any pants for sport or excercises. There, I‚Äôve said it. My name is Carlo and I don‚Äôt “do” sport. Well. Thinking it through, I came to the following conclusions:

  • I don‚Äôt know whether I will stick with it or not (I‚Äôll try to, tho).
  • I don‚Äôt like to look like a confused scuba diver with sunglasses ‚Äì no black spandex.

I was afraid my amazing efficiently working subconciousness would manage to get me lost in finding the right clothes, effectively foiling my feeble attempts at doing something. Thus, I just donned an old pair of jeans, a longsleeve shirt, a down vest and sneakers.

Now imagine my surprise‚ÄîI was able to exercise without spending shitloads of money on “Pro athlete”-themed sportswear. I believe the other jogging enthusiasts I‚Äôve met probably think I am a madman.

Hi, I‚Äôm Carlo, rebel rookie runner. How you doing?

Music: I‚Äôm currently making use of Podrunner Intervals, a free podcast for running exercises. Check it out, it‚Äôs pretty sweet, even tho the parts for running are a wee bit to slow for my taste. I‚Äôm almost 2m tall, maybe my legs are too long. ;) But I‚Äôll cope.

The single episodes are between 20 and 30 minutes long, and consist of a mix of slower and faster tracks. It‚Äôs a good mixture. Each week‚Äôs episode is going to push you a bit harder, until after 9 weeks you should be able to run 5 km in one go. We‚Äôll see how that‚Äôll work out.

The first run: Good! I‚Äôve been moving for ~30 minutes. In the end I was sweating profusely but didn‚Äôt feel like killing myself, which is a big plus. Still, it wasn‚Äôt fun. Sport, for me, simply isn‚Äôt fun. At all. That said, the “I‚Äôve done something for my body!" feeling afterwards is nice. :)

So, the sole reason I‚Äôm writing this is to keep myself from giving up prematurely. Looming shame is a powerful weapon, and this post shall be my reminder it might hit me shouldn‚Äôt I suck it up.

items.title: Planet Yahoo! updates
items.content_html:
Evening, y‚Äôall. This is Carlo, your friendly Planet Yahoo! maintainer, with a quick note.

A few hours ago I‚Äôve updated the engine that aggregates all the different Yahoo! blogs into the big purple blob that is Planet Yahoo!. Said update adds better ordering of the blog entries, and the feed parsing should be more solid. Most changes are under the hood, so nothing too interesting for the end user, i.e. you.

And it‚Äôs the same as with any update: while I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôll be problems, it might turn out I was wrong. Heh.

One minor issue: the syndication feed will be marked as ‚Äúfully updated‚Äù; so a number of older entries that you‚Äôve already marked read in your newsreader might pop up as unread again. Not to worry, this will only happen once.

The good news is that in the process I‚Äôve decided to spend some time to build a better (pardon the audacity), yet unofficial feed for the Yahoo! Research site. Also, I‚Äôve updated the MyBlogLog badge, even though I know that most of the readers never visit the site, but just subscribe to the feed.

And that‚Äôs it for today about PY!. Cheers! -C.

PS: The rest of my wacky daily adventures is currently been prepared for a multi-part TV treatment over at my blog. But you might know that already.

items.title: Sky: Brought Down
items.content_html:
This afternoon I‚Äôve finished the first/latest Mass Effect DLC, Bring Down the Sky. It adds a new mission to the game which promises ~90 minutes of gameplay, a new location, a new race and a new XBL achievement (worth 50 gamerpoints). It costs 400 MS Points (‚Ç¨4.80).

The mission was nice, nothing out of the ordinary, tho. Drive around in your Mako, clean out some places, gather ‚Äúleads‚Äù (if you want to call them that) and then face a boss guy. Make some Paragon/Renegade decisions, get a glimpse at a possible new story line to come and be done with it.

The aforementioned new location is an asteroid on a collision course with a colonised planet. The rock itself looks like pretty much like any of the old ‚Äúlesser‚Äù planets from the main game. It‚Äôs okay, not more, not less. What makes it special (to me) is the beautiful planet looming overhead ‚Äî X57, the asteroid, is heading towards Terra Nova, destined to bring doom and destruction. A grim outlook! Still pretty, tho. Seriously, it‚Äôs really shiny, but I‚Äôm a sucker for stars and planet imagery, so I might take more joy from something like this than other people.

Anyways, why is it heading there? Because of the Batarians, a race of 4-eyed humanoids. Apparently they don‚Äôt like the Humans for various historical reasons, and thus use their first on-screen appearance ever for speaking with the protagonists in a resentful manner. And for shooting at them. The audacity!

So, is ‚ÄúBring Down the Sky‚Äù a perfect DLC/addon? No. Bioware‚Äôs decision to make this an ‚Äúin-between mission‚Äù is questionable. I can understand it from a storyline point of view – too much is in flux after finishing the main game, what with the Council and all. But unfortunately it means I have to go back to a savegame where I could freely roam the galaxy – i.e. a save that was made prior to visiting Ilos etc. ‚Äî, and for some people that might be a drawback. A co-worker of mine has no save like that left, and that means he‚Äôd have to start over, and therefore he won‚Äôt pick up the DLC. So‚Ä¶ srsly, not a good decision. (Personally, I was lucky to still have a ‚Äúgood‚Äù save, tho.) But the implementation could‚Äôve been smoother. Well, I actually expected it to be smoother.

And what‚Äôs with the silent team members? I though Garrus and Kaiden were pissed since they wouldn‚Äôt talk to me during the mission. Not even random chatter. Meh. It‚Äôs a small issue, tho. Just something I found a bit strange.

All in all, tho, it‚Äôs been a nice ride. For the average price of a D√∂ner you get ~90 minutes of additional Mass Effect goodness. A good bargain in my book.

items.title: Revelation, Garden Store Edition
items.content_html:
Dana and I went to the garden store earlier today, since she‚Äôs is working on cutting back our apple tree and realised that she needs better tools for that.

Trying to be a good and interested husband, I tagged along.

Now, I don‚Äôt like garden stores. Yes, pretty flowers and all that, but I don‚Äôt like stores in general, so it‚Äôs a drag. But I wanted to help her in finding the right tools, so there.

Then it dawned me that if I would change the premise of picking out tools, I could have much more fun. So I did. My premise?

Impending Zombie attack.

I got to admin: standing in front of all the tools, discussing saws, scythes, spades and hedge shears from the point of view of someone who is preparing for a Zombie attack was actually fun. ‚ÄúHoney, look, if I could apply this thing to the small scythe here, it would give me an extra meter of reach‚Ä¶ I could probably decapitate an undead before he comes in attack range. What do you think?‚Äù ‚Äì ‚ÄúYes, that would probably work.‚Äù ‚Äì ‚ÄúWhat about the caf√© over there? How many entrances has this place? How long could we hold it?‚Äù

I may be crazy, but I feel better prepared now.

items.title: Lifestream Craziness
items.content_html:
So Friendfeed opened yesterday. Naturally, I had to sign in to take a look.

When I got to the point where it wanted me to configure the feeds and services to grab data from, it first asked for my Google Reader shared items. Okay, can do. Then it asked for my Tumblr name, and this is where my eyebrows went down.

So Tumblr allows me to bundle many of my ‚Äúactivities‚Äù in one place. Flickr, blog posts, Twitter posts, links etc., you name it. It does so by querying your Flickr account, your blog(s), Twitter, your del.icio.us bookmark dump (to name a few) via their RSS feeds. And I believe many people are using this feature just for that. I know I do. So that‚Äôs usually the first (or even second) re-posting of original content.

Now lifestream services like Friendfeed come hopping along and are going to add another level of abstraction, in the form of aggregation of already aggregated content, or an RSS feed for the aggregated lifestream, or yet another social network layer, and/or by adding comments on top of that.

How much more meta can we go? This is some Zen shit, man.

I swear, one of these days someone will put yet another layer on this Crazy Content Cake of Doom and a black hole will open in the middle of the Internet and suck out all intelligence, reason and original content. (Yes, like Digg, just a wee bit worse.)

Also, I am well aware that I, too, run my own version of a lifestream service, and that my post might seem hypocritical, but by the Gods, there‚Äôs a reason why I try to keep escaloop simple.

Update: Added some clarifications.

items.title: We're Safe, Hooray
items.content_html:
Thank the Gods, the huge pile I‚Äôve found on the sidewalk next to our door was just the remains of a friendly neighbour‚Äôs dog! Phew.

I mean, you might expect me to be upset since said friendly neighbour was too fucking lazy to pick up the steaming heap of crap his goddamn (and obviously horse-sized) mongrel left behind, but nooooo‚Ä¶ not me.

Because for a moment I was seriously afraid some sort of monstrous mutant mole had broken through the asphalt and was now terrorising my ‚Äòhood, but – phew! – it was just pooch poop.

A felt metric ton, no less.

Like, 10 meters from my door.

Motherfucks.

items.title: Podrunner...ing... I guess
items.content_html:
It‚Äôs amazing what 30 minutes of frantic walking can do for your sanity. Tonight, when getting out of the subway and noticing my bus had just left, I‚Äôve popped in a 131bpm Podrunner mix and started walking. A good 30 minutes later I found myself on my doorstep with a clear head.

Check out Podrunner, a free weekly podcast of one hour gapless music mixes for workouts and the likes. The only trick is to find a bpm range that suits you. Then put it on your iPod.

It‚Äôs simply that good.

Nerdy pro tip: once you‚Äôve found your bpm range, build a Pipe like I did and subscribe to this feed instead of the original one to only get podcasts which are ‚Äúsuited‚Äù for you. Oiy!

items.title: Site(s) Redesign Complete!
items.content_html:
I‚Äôm done with the redesign. Both my tumblelog and this blog now share the same layout and (the most important parts of the) sidebar, adding some much needed consistency.

Also I‚Äôve got rid of the Google Coop search and put the Technorati search to use instead, it‚Äôs good enough in my eyes.

The biggest change in functionality is the switch from the built-in Wordpress comments system to Disqus, on both my blog and tumblelog. Naturally, I‚Äôve added a tiny bit of logic to the Wordpress templates so the existing comments are preserved, displayed, and those entries are still accepting new comments (assuming the Comments Timeout plugin allows it). But for new entries, Disqus is used. I figured if I don‚Äôt like it, I can always switch back and cram the exported Disqus comments back into WP.

Yeah.

Now if I could use Markdown for new posts instead of Textile, I‚Äôd be a happy camper. The WP Text Control plugin is no help, unless you consider making the server drop the connection every time helping. I don‚Äôt.

Repeated tips of the hat to Bill Israel for sharing his wonderful Letterhead Tumblr theme with the crowds (CC licensing FTW!). Due to its beautifully simple semantic structure I was able to transform it into a Wordpress theme in about two hours. Thanks, Bill!

In somewhat related news: the Hendromat has launched a new tumbelog last night‚ÄîMake Games, Not Love, MGNL for short. Go check it out.

WIR K√ñNNEN DICH SEHEN

Oh Frau im Bus jeden Morgen
Oh Frau im Bus jeden Morgen

Srsly, stop it. Es gibt f√ºr alles einen Ort, aber der Bus ist es in diesem Fall nicht.

items.title: RescueTime Hack: Log your meetings and phone calls (OSX only)
items.content_html:
Over the last week I‚Äôve been using RescueTime. It‚Äôs a neat little service that‚Äôs keeping track of what you are doing all day long on your machine (Mac or PC) by logging which applications are having the focus. On the site you can then tag the different applications with different keywords (for example, my Mail.app times are tagged with ‚Äúwork‚Äù, ‚Äúcommunications‚Äù and ‚Äúemail‚Äù).

And, to make it actually useful, you can analyse your time spent, graphs and all! Check the product tour on RescueTime.com for more infos and some screenshots. It‚Äôs pretty neat. (Yes, privacy concerns, blah blah blah. It‚Äôs not the topic of this article, so please keep it to yourself for the moment. Thanks. :])

So far so good.

My problem, tho, is that I spend quite a bit of time both on the phone and in meetings. Naturally, RT won‚Äôt track these times, since these are basically off-screen activities. Uncool.

So after digging around in the RT log files I was amazed to learn they‚Äôre just YAML files. Eeeeexcellent. I can work with that!

But I wanted something with a GUI, something a bit ‚Äúcooler‚Äù than just a Ruby script. So I took this as opportunity to get a bit into Applescript. Unfortunately, RescueTime‚Äôs Mac doodad doesn‚Äôt offer an Applescript API, and I had to improvise.

After two hours of playing around and cursing at Applescript‚Äôs syntax (they‚Äôre all on crack‚Ä¶), I had something sufficiently cool to show for.

So, what is it? It‚Äôs a little application that you run everytime you want to log some off-screen time. Basically, it‚Äôs just a dialog that allows you to enter a number (i.e. minutes spent), and has some buttons to either log these minutes as ‚Äúwas on the phone‚Äù or ‚Äúwas in a meeting‚Äù. If you hit ‚ÄúCancel‚Äù, it won‚Äôt do anything. (Surprise.)

Let‚Äôs say I‚Äôve just spent 15 minutes on the phone, I‚Äôll run the application, enter ‚Äú15‚Äù and hit the Return key‚Äîand the last 15 minutes will be logged as phone call in RT. The app will quit once that‚Äôs done. Another meeting, another phone call? Rinse, repeat.

Data-wise, it‚Äôll then create a new file in the right format in RescueTime‚Äôs log directory (~/Library/RescueTime/Logs/Pending/). On the next data upload RT will pick up the new file, and it‚Äôll appear in your stats as ‚Äúmanual_phonecall‚Äù. Your meetings will appear as ‚Äúmanual_meeting‚Äù.

Please note: Neither existing RescueTime files nor the RescueTime application will be touched or tinkered with.

Below you‚Äôll find two downloads. The first one is the actual script in plain text. The second is the script compiled as application bundle. If you‚Äôre unsure which to pick, you‚Äôll most likely want the latter. ;)

  • RescueTime Log Time.applescript
  • RescueTime Log Time application (ZIP file)

Have fun.

DISCLAIMER: I‚Äôll take no responsibility for loss of data, hair or life. I am very, very sure there won‚Äôt be any losses, but still. It works for me, and I‚Äôm sharing. Use at your own risk.

items.title: Suggestions for additional explicit service support
items.content_html:
Hi all,

so far, escaloop has a couple of services it‚Äôs supporting explicitly, which means there are rules to mark these services with their own service icon and maybe an adjusted wording when they are displayed. At the time of this post, these services are:

  • del.icio.us
  • Digg
  • Facebook
  • Flickr
  • Google (search results etc.)
  • Google Reader (shared items)
  • Last.fm
  • Livejournal
  • Magnolia
  • Newsvine
  • Pownce
  • StumbleUpon
  • Tumblr
  • Twitter
  • Vimeo
  • Vox.com

Everything else is supported implicitly, which means it‚Äôs processed and displayed, but has no special icon or anything, it‚Äôs ‚Äújust‚Äù another source.

So my question today is: do you have suggestions for other services that should be explicitly supported? If yes, please reply to this topic and provide both the URL to service/site as well as (if possible) an example feed or two so I can take a look. I won‚Äôt promise to include each and every suggestion; unfortunately, my spare time isn‚Äôt unlimited, and also it doesn‚Äôt make sense to support everything explicitely, methinks.

Well, please tell me what you want! It certainly can‚Äôt hurt. ;) Many thanks!

(I‚Äôve closed the comments here, please sound off on the escaloop discussion board instead.)

items.title: escaloop v1.1 - Speedier, Facebookier, Diggier.
items.content_html:
I‚Äôve spent the last few hours bug testing, then deploying, then yelling at, then hotfixing, then re-deploying a new version of both escaloop site and badge. I didn‚Äôt include everything I was planning on initially, and instead decided to go for ‚Äúrelease early, release often‚Äù.

A few highlights:

  • Added some juice and stability‚Äîhopefully everything runs a bit faster more solid now.
  • New feature: Source list, add a pretty list of all feeds in a badge to the end of the badge. Check the demo badge for an example and the badge builder for the new config option.

items.title: Mini Review: Mass Effect, Xbox 360
items.content_html:
Okay, yes, I‚Äôm late to the review party. In my defense, it has something to do with this and the fact that I wanted to finish Mass Effect twice before rendering my judgement.

So, my first playthrough on normal difficulty was very thorough. I‚Äôve picked a male (Infiltrator class), took the ‚Äúgood guy‚Äù approach (‚ÄúWe have to save the galaxy! – Wait, what‚Äôs that, old lady? Your kitten is trapped in this death maze? We‚Äôll help!‚Äù), also did pretty much every sidequest I could find, landed on every rock available, and ended up spending 34 hours or so. Hey, my char even had freaky, slightly awkward (in the build-up) alien sex with that endlessly blabbering blueberry. Dynomite.

The second time around I rolled a female (Soldier class) and played the whole game on hardcore difficulty in a ‚ÄúI have a job to do, get out of my way‚Äù kind of way. Short-tempered, gun-in-your-face attitude, not afraid to leave a crater. In short, for the most part I tried to play it like time actually mattered. This time I clocked in ~14 hours. And this time, my leading lady ended up ripping the clothes off one of her male subordinates. Oh, and she had freaky, surprising lesbian alien sex with some random NPC, without meaning to.

Shiny.

The game‚Äôs not without flaws, tho. The sidequests on the planets are a wee bit repetitive. There are some rather frequent framerate drops and ‚ÄúHalo 2‚Äù-style texture pop-in issues after the loading screens. Background noises were sometimes awfully quiet, and it was really, really hard to make them out, which made some surroundings appear a bit sterile in the aural department. The squad NPC pathfinding took a short break from time to time, making me run back to show one of my compadres how to walk around the car. Oh, and Bioware? My wife asks whether for ME2 you could add some more samples to enemy NPCs, I think if she has to hear ‚ÄúI will destroy you!‚Äù or ‚ÄúGo! Go! Go!‚Äù one more time, she‚Äôll be going postal.

But ultimately, in my book, it‚Äôs really a great game. Hey, it‚Äôs mostly ‚ÄúKnights of the Old Republic‚Äù, albeit with a lot of changes! It might not perfect, but it comes close. The player char‚Äôs gender does make a difference every now and then. I liked the majority of the voice acting, the stories and side-quests were mostly laid out well, and the presentation was usually top notch. Especially the last 1-2 hours were mighty fine. Cinematical, even. Wonderful, wonderful build up of tension.

All in all I‚Äôve spent around 50-60 hours on Mass Effect, and enjoyed those. I recommend it.

items.title: escaloop.com is go!
items.content_html:
A few months ago I was talking to Hendrik about lifestreams, and in my ongoing struggle for his undying love (as a friend), I‚Äôve whipped up a little somethingsomething using the wonderful Yahoo! Pipes.

‚ÄúLifestream?‚Äù, you ask. ‚ÄúWhat the deuce is a lifestream?!‚Äù A good question. A lifestream is basically a big bucket where all the updates and update notifications from your blog, your ADD-induced Twitter posts, your Flickr uploads etc come together in one concise way so it‚Äôs easier for others to ignore them. ;) Also, you only have one URL to hand out to hot women (or men) in pubs because the stream inadvertedly works as a hub page, too!

Now, while the prototype was quickly hacked together, it felt clunky. Sure, you can pass a dozen URLs or so to the pipe, but what if the URLs would change? Or if you wanted to add a new one or delete one from the list? Then it‚Äôd be a lot of tinkering with the script call in your HTML code.

So I had the idea to build a site where you could configure the list of URLs and the layout and everything, and which would give you a HTML badge for your blog or site, a snippet that wouldn‚Äôt change.

And today, I proudly open escaloop to the public.

I feel it‚Äôs good enough to test the waters, I believe. I‚Äôve played around with it, fiddling with different implementations on different types of pages, and it looks okay. I guess I could try to think of every possibility for every site on earth, but we know how that would turn out.

It certainly looks fine on my own blog. (Considering that I don‚Äôt have that many active feeds, that is.)

So with that, I‚Äôll release escaloop into the wild. It‚Äôs still a bit rough around the edges, and there might be bugs. That said: Please take a look, play around with it, build yourself a badge or two for your site, blog, MySpace page, whatever. If you have feedback, please let me know in the escaloop Google Group.

Have fun, Carlo

PS: You might ask what took me so long. In my defense, I am a lazy bastard. Also, I wrote the first rough draft in Python, then switched to Ruby. There I‚Äôve wrote the first prototype using the Sinatra DSL, and finally settled to make use of nifty lightweight Ramaze framework. (By the way, Sinatra is nice, but not what I was looking for.)

During the last few months I‚Äôve also had to put a lot of time into Mass Effect, which is a great game. You understand.

items.title: Open Facebook
items.content_html:
(Disclaimer: The following paragraphs might be pointless and you might end up feeling I have once again stated the obvious. So‚Ä¶ you‚Äôve been warned.)

TechCrunch reports on Google apparently working with some unnamed industry bigshots on opening up their social networks services.

Yesterday a select group of fifteen or so industry luminaries attended a highly confidential meeting at Google‚Äôs headquarters in Mountain View to discuss the company‚Äôs upcoming plans to address the ‚ÄúFacebook issue.‚Äù [‚Ä¶] Google‚Äôs goal ‚Äì to fight Facebook by being even more open than the Facebook Platform. If Facebook is 98% open, Google wants to be 100%.

Well, we‚Äôll see how that‚Äôll pan out.

I have been discussing the whole Facebook API thing with friends and co- workers over the past few weeks. You are constantly hearing about how cool it is that ‚ÄúFacebook is open‚Äù, that everyone can build FB applications and become wealthy and all that jazz, but most people have already figured something out‚Äîit isn‚Äôt open. It‚Äôs a goddamn closed system.

So let‚Äôs assume you want to use their rich API set to build the next killer application and get rich in the process. How‚Äôs that going to work? Yes, you can build cool stuff. Definitely. It‚Äôs just‚Äîhow are you going to monetize your work? In the end, in my eyes, there are but two types of applications:

  1. Advertisements, i.e. marketing widgets/apps that display links (in different forms, of course), trying to get the user to click through to a non-FB site.
  2. For-fun apps like games or graffiti-wall-alikes, which completely run within the boundaries of FB and never leave them.

And that’s the thing. Either you’re building something that is basically an eye-catcher for your already existing site, not unlike a digital carnival barker, and hope to get attention and visitors coming from Facebook to your site. Or you build something far more complex, inside Facebook, without a viable way to make money from it. Which might cool from a hobbyist point of view, but is crap when you build things for a living. What’s built for Facebook stays in Facebook.

Hendrik noted the other day that if there was some sort of ‚ÄúFacebook points‚Äù (akin to Xbox Live Arcade points or Linden Dollars), i.e. micropayments, the situation would be far more interesting for professionals. And he‚Äôs right. Alas, there‚Äôs no such thing. Too bad.

So, to me, it seems that right now everyone developing real applications within Facebook is an unpaid semi-employee of Facebook.com. If you need to make money on the web to put food on your own table, I don‚Äôt think is an option. There is no incentive. So far, Facebook is a purely hobbyist platform. End of story.

I might be completely wrong about this, mind you. But I still don‚Äôt understand all the applause and excitement about the prospect of writing Facebook applications. Just saying.

micropayments, the situation would be far more interesting for professionals.
And he‚Äôs right. Alas, there‚Äôs no such thing. Too bad.

So, to me, it seems that right now everyone developing _real_ applications within Facebook is an unpaid semi-employee of [Facebook.com][3]. If you need to make money on the web to put food on your own table, I don‚Äôt think is an option. There is no incentive. So far, Facebook is a purely hobbyist platform.
End of story.

I might be completely wrong about this, mind you. But I still don‚Äôt understand all the applause and excitement about the prospect of writing Facebook applications. Just saying.

items.title: Yahoo! Pipes Tutorial: How To Process HTML Pages
items.content_html:
Over the weekend I finally had some time to continue playing around with Yahoo! Pipes. (Turns out that quitting World of Warcraft makes your days longer. Huh. Who’d have thought‚Ä¶) It really is a neat toy/tool.

Alas, it is not without hitches. If you’ve worked with Pipes before, you know that it has a module named ‘Fetch Data’, but unfortunately this module is only able to deal with XML and JSON data. It’s just that it will outright reject anything else. And most HTML pages fall in this category.

Here’s my story on how I managed to make Pipes process run-of-the-mill HTML pages. I couldn’t find anything on this topic on the net, so even though I don’t think I am the first guy to tackle this problem, I want to share what I found out.

A little background. I wanted to build a comic feed for Explosm.net’s Cyanide & Happiness, a comic strip for the ‚Ä¶wicked. C&H has an official RSS feed, but it only carries links to the new comic pages. Which is fine and dandy for most people, but I am a busy guy, you know, what with my hectic web-3.1 lifestyle and all, and I really can’t afford to even lose 20 seconds by clicking through to anywhere. (Read: I’m really lazy.)

So I tried to make Pipes to parse the Explosm.net comic pages and produce a Pipes-powered feed that not only had the link, but also the particular comic image for that day.

I started out with the Fetch Feed module reading the Explosm.net RSS feed. I am usually not interested in anything but the comics, so in a second step, I made use of the Filter module to ditch feed items that doesn’t contain the word “comic”.

So that left me with a list of feed items, each with a link, a description, a title and some other metadata.

That’s where the trouble started. Boy, what was I thinking?! The HTML pages are far from perfect, they sure as hell doesn’t validate as XML. Then again ‚Äî that’s alright! The site wasn’t made for scraping or parsing, it was made to display -tasteful- weird comic strips, and that’s enough. I like it for that. It’s just that there is no Pipes module to grab a glob of textual data and work with it. (Yet? Please, someone say “Yet”, employing a knowing undertone.)

After a while of trying to beat any of the available ‘Fetch *’ modules into submission, I was close to giving up. But then I remember I had come across a HTML Tidy service a few months or years ago. After a few minutes, I had rediscovered it: W3C’s own Tidy service. It’ll digest any HTML page (you just pass the address), and it will clean it up and return valid a XHTML document, which also constitutes as XML. Huzzah!

Well then, commence plumbing! The third module I used was the wonderful Loop module. It’s special because it will process every item in a given dataset, in this case it’d iterate over all remaining feed items. I’ve told the Loop module to use the String Builder module, there I concatenated the Tidy URL, http://cgi.w3.org/cgi-bin/tidy?forceXML=on&docAddr=, with the item.link attribute, and assigned the resulting string to a new a attribute, item.link_tidy.

Step four consisted of another Loop, in which I would use a Fetch Data module to grab the data from the Tidy’d Explosm.net pages, which had now been transformed into neat and valid XML structures and therefore could be digested by the module. It took me a few minutes to find the exact location of the image element (body.div.table.tr.td.div.0.div.1.table.tr.td.1.div.font.0.content), which I then stored in a new attribute named item.content.

(While we’re at it, in the future I would very much like to have the option to use XPath addressing in ‘Fetch Data’‚Ä¶ or any related module, for that matter. Thanks in advance. :) )

Anyways, the next steps are using yet another Loop to concatenate the image HTML with the original item.description, and then another one to rewrite the original image URLs a bit so the images are served through the free and excellent Coral Distribution Network.

(Technically, I might not be stealing from Explosm.net, especially since they allow hotlinking of their comic strips from message boards and pretty much anywhere, but for the sake of this example and story here, and the assumption that a few people might end up cloning the Pipe ‚Äî yes, I am a dreamer ‚Äî, I feel a bit better knowing I leave less of a footprint on their image servers.)

Then it was applying a Reverse module to flip the order of the items (a cosmetical issue), and that was it.

So, to sum up this long and rather tedious story: you can process HTML pages with Yahoo! Pipes. It’s just not as straightforward as you would expect.

Well, and if you want to take a look at it: here’s the finished Pipe ‚Äî it might not look like much since the HTML preview doesn’t show the images, but the RSS output is complete.

Tip o' the hat to Cyanide & Happiness for mindblowing hijinx, the W3C for the free & open Tidy service, and the CDN for being good people.

Now go and use Yahoo! Pipes. It’s one of the cooler products we (as a company) have released in the last few years, and quite frankly, it deserves praise.

So there.

Quick links: Finished Pipe, RSS Output

Update, 2007-09-19:* I’ve slightly adjusted the element addressing in the Pipe to waterproof it a bit. The general idea and order of the modules didn’t change, tho.

Update, 2007-12-07: My technique has been superceded by the offical new Fetch Page module ‚Äî enjoy! :)

items.title: Cordless Hardware Is Killing Your Children
items.content_html:
Okay, maybe that was a bit harsh, but think about it for a moment. Everyone is complaining about power consumption and global warming and whatnot, THE EARTH IS DYING!!!1oneoneeleven, yet by now it‚Äôs really fucking hard to find a decent mouse or keyboard that does have a cable.

Why is that?

I seriously don‚Äôt understand why it‚Äôs necessary and accepted among computer users to have a formerly cable-bound piece of hardware that now doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúneed‚Äù a cable anymore, but batteries (rechargable or not). Or worse: the mice that come with their own base stations and power adapters.

Mind you, your mouse and keyboard are usually around 50cm to 1m away from your Mac or PC. So why not use something with a cable?

I am currently shopping for a new mouse, hence the confusion. Well, actually I am annoyed. I was eying the beautiful Logitech MX Revolution, which is a wonderful piece of equipment, is ergonomic, has the right size for my paws, it would be perfect!

Unfortunately (for Logitech) I refuse to buy something as mundane as a pointing device with its own PCU. Sure, they probably don‚Äôt care.

/sigh

items.title: We're NOT Friends, Sorry
items.content_html:
Twitter and Pownce are broken. MySpace, too. Oh, and pretty much every social networking site on the planet, too. For me, at least.

It‚Äôs not the technical aspect. Not the concept, either.

(Well, I don‚Äôt understand the hype and/or praise sites like Twitter is getting. From a technical standpoint, it‚Äôs well done, I won‚Äôt argue that, but I don‚Äôt get the point of the sites. But back to the topic.)

No, it‚Äôs the semantics.

You see, offline, I don‚Äôt call many people ‚Äúfriend‚Äù. This doesn‚Äôt mean I am surrounded by unpleasant people, quite the contrary. But I make a difference between friends and pals or contacts. A friend is someone I would risk my life for. Usually this two-way trust has grown over a few years, and is something important to me.

Now, online, I am expected to call every Tom, Dick or Harry ‚Äúfriend‚Äù, and somehow, that doesn‚Äôt work for me. I create an account at, let‚Äôs say, Pownce, and am instantly bombarded by new friend requests. Usually by people I haven‚Äôt spoken to before, let alone met.

Yeah‚Ä¶ I am afraid I can‚Äôt do that, Digital Dave.

Sites like Flickr do it differently. People are ‚Äúcontacts‚Äù. If I decided I like them, I can promote them to ‚Äúfriends‚Äù or ‚Äúfamily‚Äù. Which is okay. If we have spoken online, maybe in the office, maybe even met, then I am willing to add you as ‚Äúcontact‚Äù. That‚Äôs cool and not diminishing our relationship.

And this is my point: just calling someone ‚Äúcontact‚Äù instead of ‚Äúfriend‚Äù doesn‚Äôt mean I don‚Äôt like that person. It just means I don‚Äôt know him/her well enough to consider him/her a ‚Äúfriend‚Äù. Because to me, this word has a meaning. Shying away from labeling you ‚Äúfriend‚Äù isn‚Äôt impolite, it‚Äôs honest. Because we are not friends.

There are people I am fond of, people I like, but with whom I am not that close. I enjoy hanging out with them, and I enjoy their company, but they‚Äôre not my friends. And that is perfectly alright, for both them and myself.

(Truth to be told, it wasn‚Äôt always like this. But I‚Äôm growing older, and my views change.)

Another example: The other day there was a bit of drama in our little WoW guild. There was a younger lad who we were playing and chatting with quite often. At some point, he felt thoroughly insulted when Christian (pal of mine) and I kindly tried to explain to him that we were not his friends. Heck, we had never met. We were playing an online game together, and chatting a lot while doing so. We tried to get the message across, tried to explain that we liked him, but we didn‚Äôt consider him a friend in the true sense. He got upset and left the guild in anger.

Well, it happens. Not much I can do about it.

The net is our (relatively) new world. Our habits are changing, human relationships might, too‚Äîat least a bit. Still, should we abandon our values? If everyone is a ‚Äúfriend‚Äù, it means nobody is. For me, this prospect leaves a lot to be desired.

Dear site builders, please stop trying to build a virtual Woodstock. I know you‚Äôre probably just trying to achieve a feeling of ‚ÄúI belong here‚Äù for your users so they come back, but for God‚Äôs sake, stop making me pretend I care equally about everyone. Because I don‚Äôt.

‚Äî

Anyways, my personal proposal is the use of ‚Äúwebster‚Äù. I‚Äôve checked Wikipedia, the original meaning of the word has kind of ‚Äúexpired‚Äù, so let‚Äôs re-use it. :) Are you with me, people?

items.title: "Web 2.0", "AJAX", "BARF" - A Call To Action
items.content_html:
After reading another great press release I think I now know what ‚ÄúWeb 2.0‚Äù means. Up until now I was convinced that if you asked 10 people what it means, you‚Äôd get 10 different answers. Turns out all the tech guys have it wrong, tho.

You see, it‚Äôs all in the pronunciation. It‚Äôs not ‚ÄúWeb two-point-zero‚Äù, it‚Äôs actually ‚ÄúWeb two-point-oh‚Äù. As in ‚ÄúWeb two-point-OH-MY-GOD WE‚ÄôRE, LIKE, TOTALLY COOL‚Äù.

Don‚Äôt laugh.

The other day I looked with a friendly non-tech guy at some purdy web pages. (I am not dissing him for not knowing this stuff, he is not a programmer, which is completely okay. I am just telling this to illustrate a point.) It went like this:

Guy, pointing: ‚ÄúThat looks pretty cool, what with it sliding out smoothly and all! Ah, Web 2.0, great. Is that AJAX?‚Äù

Me: ‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs a ‚Äòdropdown‚Äô.‚Äù

Guy, pointing: ‚ÄúOr here, all these big image things with the text, that is Web 2.0, right?‚Äù

Me: ‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs static images with text link overlays.‚Äù

Thank you, crazy Internet marketing hype machine. I wish you weren‚Äôt decentralized so I could come visit and burn you down.

That term should be banned from the face of the net. Every time I tell people I work on the Intertubes for a living, it‚Äôs always ‚ÄúWow, like Web 2.0?‚Äù.

Okay, fellow tech guys, listen up, this needs to stop. I propose answering questions like that with ‚ÄúNo, not ‚ÄòWeb 2.0‚Äô and ‚ÄòAJAX‚Äô, we‚Äôre doing BARF now. ‚ÄòBARF‚Äô stands for ‚ÄòBidirectional Asynchronous Request Forwarding‚Äô, it‚Äôs hot right now. I could explain it, but it‚Äôd probably take too long. There‚Äôs a number of articles on oreilly.com, look it up, it‚Äôs great. It‚Äôs going to be in the next release of Django and Rails, man‚Äîright in the core, built-in!!‚Äù

Don‚Äôt tell me it wouldn‚Äôt work, don‚Äôt tell me it wouldn‚Äôt work.

If you‚Äôre laughing right now or thinking I am just saying this, you‚Äôre mistaken. Let‚Äôs turn the Bullshit Train around. I am dead serious.

‚Äî

Update #1: The acronym was inspired by the fine Iranian soap products, of course.

Update #2: I changed the phrase from ‚ÄúBitwise Asynchronous Request Forwarding‚Äù to ‚ÄúBidirectional Asynchronous Request Forwarding‚Äù. It just makes more sense that way.

items.title: Revelation, Web 2.0 edition
items.content_html:
It just dawned me that on the web, Germany must be to the UK and US what China is to the rest of the ‚Äúreal‚Äù World (at least in the perception of the rich western countries): copycats.

Cases in point: Frazr vs. Twitter, StudiVZ vs. Facebook, a dozen del.icio.us clones vs. del.icio.us.

Seriously, the (visible part of the) German startup scene is making a sad impression. Pretty much each new German site I see is more or less a carbon copy of a successful UK or US site. The other day I was even approached whether I wanted to help clone Pownce (‚ÄúHey, how quickly could one copy a site like that?‚Äù). What happened to ingenuity and/or integrity?

I really start to believe I know the only original guy around.

items.content_html:
Dear Perl community,

I just wasted 15 minutes of my life trying to figure out how to get the index of a particular element in an array. Turns out I have to write a for loop to walk through the array. This is insulting.

Seriously, it‚Äôs 2007. If at this point in time you‚Äôre still defending your beloved language and/or using words like ‚Äúelegant‚Äù or ‚Äúquick‚Äù when describing Perl, you‚Äôre bat shit crazy. My 2c.

Love, Carlo.

Addendum, 2007-07-04, 9:14 CEST: I forgot to mention a few things.

  • It wasn‚Äôt my choice to use Perl, I just have to deal with it.
  • I was talking about a very limited set of unique strings.
  • The Perl Cookbook offered a solution, which is seven lines of code, the core being a for loop.

items.title: Weissbier with Timberlake
items.content_html:
The other day I met Justin Timberlake at a bus station here in Munich.

That was quite bizarre, he was just standing there, apparently waiting for the bus. At first, I wasn‚Äôt sure whether it was really him; just a guy in a shirt, jeans and a jacket. I glanced at him a couple of times, the man looked a wee bit pissed, but not too much. You know how it is‚Äîyou look at someone, wondering whether your mind is playing tricks on you, or whether you‚Äôre going crazy, because what you see is highly improbable.

After two minutes I‚Äôve decided to say something. He had noticed me glancing, but hadn‚Äôt said anything. And there‚Äôs only so much glancing you can do before it becomes impolite or even rude.

I cleared my throat. ‚ÄúMr. Timberlake?‚Äù, I asked.

He looked at me, still appearing a bit pissed.

‚ÄúAllow me to introduce myself,‚Äù I‚Äôve said. ‚ÄúMy name‚Äôs Carlo Zottmann, I live here, and I work on the interwebs for a living.‚Äù

His brows narrowed a bit; puzzled, he appeared to be.

‚ÄúI like your music. Not everything, but a couple of your songs are rather cool. Just wanted to let you know.‚Äù With that, I smiled and turned away.

After a moment he said, ‚ÄúWhy did you tell me that?‚Äù

I turned back to face him. ‚ÄúWell, I know who you are and what you do. I think it‚Äôs only fair to level the playing field. And claiming I‚Äôd be your biggest fan and have all your albums would be a lie, so why do it.‚Äù

He grinned. ‚ÄúTrue.‚Äù And that was that, then.

Or not. Half a minute later and turned to me again and asked, ‚ÄúDo you know a pub or something around here?‚Äù

Heh.

That‚Äôs how I ended up having a Weissbier with him at the Lehner‚Äôs in Trudering. Who‚Äôd have thought? Turned out he was dumped by some woman in the middle of Munich without his entourage (he didn‚Äôt want to go into details, but I think it was planned to be a romantic evening), and he didn‚Äôt feel like calling them. Instead he had opted for walking around a bit. Makes sense, Munich isn‚Äôt that big. We talked about our families and life, the job, the usual stuff. That was pretty cool, I have to admit. He‚Äôs just another bloke, his job seems to be more glamorous than mine, but only a bit.

Fun fact: almost noone seemed to recognize him. I ordered for him, and there are a lot of english speakers in town anyways, so hearing another language is not unusual. Heh. When bringing us the bill, the waitress caught a closer look and for a moment seemed to faint. J‚Äôs expression hardened ever so slightly, and he seemed to prepare himself for the unavoidable things to come, but I manage to interrupt.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt. Please.‚Äù, I asked her.

‚ÄúBut‚Ä¶ this is‚Ä¶‚Äù, she started.

‚ÄúI know who he is. Please, don‚Äôt. Show some mercy.‚Äù I grinned at her. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think he‚Äôll object to giving you an autograph, but give the man some quiet time.‚Äù

She pondered it for a moment, and finally smiled. ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúThanks.‚Äù

So he paid for the food and the drinks, gave her the promised autograph, and then we slipped out. By then it was night, and the humidity of the day had vanished a bit.

‚ÄúWell, thanks for the beer, Carlo.‚Äù he said.

I took the offered hand. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt pay. Thank you. Hey, need a lift or anything? I could call Dana, we could bring you back to the hotel‚Ä¶‚Äù

He interrupted me with a quick shake of his head. ‚ÄúNah, ‚Äôs cool. I‚Äôll walk back. Or take the subway.‚Äù

‚ÄúReally? You sure?‚Äù

‚ÄúYour town is tiny. I‚Äôll manage.‚Äù

‚ÄúScrew you, Timberlake. Munich fuckin‚Äô rocks.‚Äù

He laughed. ‚ÄúTake care.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou, too.‚Äù

After that, I walked home. It‚Äôs only 20 minutes by foot, and it helped me to clear my head. Dana couldn‚Äôt believe what I told her after coming through the door, and was (understandably) a bit miffed I didn‚Äôt call her when we we‚Äôre still at the restaurant. I promised her to let her know right away the next time I met a celebrity at the bus station. Heh.

And that was how I had a drink with Justin Timberlake, of all people.

Now, this anecdote has been one of the greatest in my life, and is obviously completely made up. I consider it an excercise in LIEterature. So there.

I turned back to face him. ‚ÄúWell, I know who you are and what you do. I think it‚Äôs only fair to level the playing field. And claiming I‚Äôd be your biggest fan and have all your albums would be a lie, so why do it.‚Äù

He grinned. ‚ÄúTrue.‚Äù And that was that, then.

Or not. Half a minute later and turned to me again and asked, ‚ÄúDo you know a pub or something around here?‚Äù

Heh.

That‚Äôs how I ended up having a [Weissbier][1] with him at the [Lehner‚Äôs][2] in Trudering. Who‚Äôd have thought? Turned out he was dumped by some woman in the middle of Munich _without his entourage_ (he didn‚Äôt want to go into details,
but I think it was planned to be a romantic evening), and he didn‚Äôt feel like calling them. Instead he had opted for walking around a bit. Makes sense,
Munich isn‚Äôt that big. We talked about our families and life, the job, the usual stuff. That was pretty cool, I have to admit. He‚Äôs just another bloke,
his job seems to be more glamorous than mine, but only a bit.

Fun fact: almost noone seemed to recognize him. I ordered for him, and there are a lot of english speakers in town anyways, so hearing another language is not unusual. Heh. When bringing us the bill, the waitress caught a closer look and for a moment seemed to faint. J‚Äôs expression hardened ever so slightly,
and he seemed to prepare himself for the unavoidable things to come, but I manage to interrupt.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt. _Please._‚Äù, I asked her.

‚ÄúBut‚Ä¶ this is‚Ä¶‚Äù, she started.

‚ÄúI know who he is. Please, don‚Äôt. Show some mercy.‚Äù I grinned at her. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think he‚Äôll object to giving you an autograph, but give the man some quiet time.‚Äù

She pondered it for a moment, and finally smiled. ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúThanks.‚Äù

So he paid for the food and the drinks, gave her the promised autograph, and then we slipped out. By then it was night, and the humidity of the day had vanished a bit.

‚ÄúWell, thanks for the beer, Carlo.‚Äù he said.

I took the offered hand. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt pay. Thank you. Hey, need a lift or anything? I could call Dana, we could bring you back to the hotel‚Ä¶‚Äù

He interrupted me with a quick shake of his head. ‚ÄúNah, ‚Äôs cool. I‚Äôll walk back. Or take the subway.‚Äù

‚ÄúReally? You sure?‚Äù

‚ÄúYour town is tiny. I‚Äôll manage.‚Äù

‚ÄúScrew you, Timberlake. Munich fuckin‚Äô rocks.‚Äù

He laughed. ‚ÄúTake care.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou, too.‚Äù

After that, I walked home. It‚Äôs only 20 minutes by foot, and it helped me to clear my head. Dana couldn‚Äôt believe what I told her after coming through the door, and was (understandably) a bit miffed I didn‚Äôt call her when we we‚Äôre still at the restaurant. I promised her to let her know right away the next time I met a celebrity at the bus station. Heh.

And that was how I had a drink with Justin Timberlake, of all people.

Now, this anecdote has been one of the greatest in my life, and is obviously completely made up. I consider it an excercise in [LIEterature][3]. So there.

[2]: http://www.lehners-wirtshaus.de/
[3]: http://doodleplex.com/glassmaze/index.php/lieterature

items.title: Madrid, or Whoaholycraphowcoolisthat
items.content_html:
The other day I talked about our impending doom, but Madrid wasn‚Äôt totally bad.

In fact, I had two great nights there. On Monday, after I‚Äôve arrived, my esteemed colleagues and I went to a little tapas restaurant whose name I forgot. Too bad, because it was rather spiffy. Nice food, great wine, much fun. We actually walked there from the office, so I managed to get some quick glimpses at the city. Beats driving around in a taxi.

On Tuesday, the good folks of Yahoo! Spain took us to Casa Patas, a Flamenco-themed restaurant. Really nice food, good wine (once again). Around 22:30 we‚Äôve all been really stuffed, and wondering where to go next, when we were told that there was a Flamenco show coming up, and we had tickets.

Now, mind you, I had no idea what to expect. Flamenco had never really appeared on my radar prior to that evening.

To make it short: it was one hell of a show. There were three singers, Pepe Jim√©nez, Jos√© ‚ÄúEl Flaco‚Äù and Pedro Jim√©nez, two guitars, Jesus Losada and Victor ‚ÄúEl Tomate‚Äù (I am not making this up, it‚Äôs what the pamphlet said). Also, three dancers: Primitivo Daza, Miguel Canas and Rosa Jim√©nez. (Thanks to David for letting me use the picture.)

And quite frankly, they rocked the house.

The music was superb. The dancing was mindblowing. It was an awesome evening, and I was completely blown away. The other guys had a good time as well, and it‚Äôs been quite something!

Many thanks to both Marcos and Arno from the Madrid office for planning a great night out. Here‚Äôs hoping you‚Äôll never come to Munich because quite frankly, I wouldn‚Äôt know how to top that. ;)

Unfortunately, I still have no idea what kind of Flamenco I had witnessed. Apparently there are around 50 different styles of Flamenco, and I am a total n00b when it comes to classifying kickass foreign ethno entertainment. :p After spending some time listening to many different artists (Pandora.com and Last.fm be praised), I hadn‚Äôt made any progress. So I‚Äôve asked my Spanish coworkers, and they couldn‚Äôt tell me either.

Then I‚Äôve mailed the folks at Casa Patas (in English), explaining which show I had seen, and asking whether they could tell me the subtype(s) of Flamenco that were shown this evening, and guess what I got back? A form letter, in Spanish, with a rather lengthy Word document, describing the history of Flamenco, in Spanish. Gee, thanks. I wonder what made them think I could speak Spanish, after writing them in another language. ;)

So, that didn‚Äôt help either. It means listening to more music then, hoping to find something I might like. Well, that can‚Äôt hurt, but it‚Äôs driving me nuts to listen and listen and listen and not find the right thing.

Before discovering the Internet I‚Äôve had a bit more patience, I think.

items.title: Good bye, Media Temple
items.content_html:
After giving Media Temple a go for a few months regarding hosting this little blog on their much-touted plan/platform, I‚Äôve decided it‚Äôs definitely not worth $20/month for me.

Seriously, it‚Äôs just a wee blog, nothing big. In fact, it‚Äôs mostly a plain vanilla Wordpress setup. Nothing special there. And also I don‚Äôt get many visitors, so I was surprised to see the site to awfully slow. What gives? On top of that is the SSH access responding at glacier speeds at any given time; very underwhelming, too.

So I‚Äôve packed my things and set up shop at A Small Orange. It‚Äôs small, it‚Äôs (said to be) reliable, and the change has been astounding (to me). It‚Äôs nothing fancy in the sense that they redefine web hosting or anything, they just host my stuff, and that‚Äôs it. Which is fine.

In the end, I pay a 1/4 of what Media Temple cost me, and in return get something that is more like what I was looking for. At least for the last two days. ;)

I might keep you updated about the long(er) term experience.

Update 2007-06-15: Some small grammatical fixes.

items.title: Madrid, or Why we're all doomed
items.content_html:
A few days ago, the company sent me to Madrid, Spain, for a summit.

Madrid was nice. I‚Äôve met a lot of friendly people, co-workers and random passersby alike, taxi drivers and dancers (more on that later), and made some observation which lead me to believe our attempts at saving the climate are futile.

In short: from what I observed over the course of three days, along with what I‚Äôve seen during our days on Teneriffe, Spain‚Äôs collective consciousness doesn‚Äôt seem to give a damn about energy conservation.

Don‚Äôt get me wrong, please. Germany is far from being perfect and totally awesome in that regard, but most people are trying by now. Also the government tries to get people to conserve energy, to recycle, to re-use things. Hell, I remember the recycling ads from my childhood, so apparently the effort is made for a good number of years by now.

But Spain‚Ä¶ man, this was nuts. One-off styrofoam cups everywhere. Two or three plastic cups at the watercooler, at once, which are thrown away after one go. (I mean, why wouldn‚Äôt you, there are many more available.) I was hard pressed to find four (4!) ceramic cups in the entire office, and used one of those then. (Seriously, I am not recycling my pants off for years just to start using styrofoam cups again while being away.) People leaving their cars running while they were waiting for someone on the street, for 10 minutes, 15 minutes‚Ä¶ Incredible. (Apparently fuel isn’t expensive enough yet.) And so on.

Then I talked to a colleague from France who told me that they started a ‚Äúlet‚Äôs recycle, everybody!‚Äù campaign last year or so. Last year. Which means that until last year, the concept seemed foreign to them.

There were more little things I‚Äôve noticed which made me raise my eyebrows every now and then. Now, I am not a tree hugger and I don‚Äôt think I am the awesomest dude around when it comes to energy conservation and reducing waste (thusly reducing CO2 production). But if you‚Äôre a concerned human which at this point everyone should be, I think, then you can‚Äôt look at shit like this and help but twitch.

In the end it is a governmental fault. See, here in Germany the political caste has adopted CO2 reduction as an urgent issue, and sometimes they even do act accordingly. But even if they don‚Äôt they usually present it as burning issue, and hearing it over and over again, many people have adjusted or are at least starting to. Somehow the system kindasorta works, even if it could work better, but we‚Äôre getting there‚Ä¶ I hope. None of us is without sin, so there.

But apparently a lot of European countries seem to hope the problem might just go away by itself. Which I find highly disturbing and which makes me think we‚Äôre all doomed.

UPDATE: This here post deserved a less doomy follow-up.

items.title: Carlo & The Carpet Cutter
items.content_html:
A week ago I was doing some home improvement. Well, I tried. And failed. In a spectacular way‚Äîthe carpet cutter slipped and chopped through the back of my thumb.

For a split second I had a clear look at my joint, then it got messy.

Well, Dana got me to the ER ‚Äì not after saving my life, tho! Standing upright next to the stairs (upper end), I lost consciousness for about 30 seconds. She grabbed and yelled at me, and after a while I blinked and was back. Oiy.

Anyways, we got into the ER, and the friendly lady at the reception desk said “What’s wrong?", and I could finally say the one thing I had always envisioned, yet never had the chance to pull off.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm bleeding.‚Äù

Had to grin a bit after I‚Äôve said it. So worth it. (Well, not really.)

To make a long story short, they stitched my thumb together again. Turns out I had actually really reached the joint, and even partially cut a tendon. Splendid.

Now my whole hand is in a cast.

Typing is slow as molasses, mostly because the freaking cast is in the way. The stitches are starting to itch, which probably is a good thing, but that doesn‚Äôt make it better.

The doc gave me two weeks off, and until then, the web is mostly ‚Äúread-only‚Äù for me. Because writing is slow, as mentioned‚Äîthis blog entry took half an hour.

items.title: Maga-what? Reading Habit Meme
items.content_html:
Huh, so I‚Äôve been tagged by Frank. Splendid. :P

I‚Äôve used to read quite a few magazines in the day, mostly to feed my habit (PC gaming, back then); a remnant of happy times past, when I was a kid. You see, I grew up in Eastern Germany, and while I had no problems or real shortcomings there, I never really had the chance to buy computer magazines of any sort (programming, gaming etc.)‚Äîsimply because there were none.

Well, then one happy day, friends of my parents from Western Germany visited us, and lo and behold, they brought a few dozen (slightly outdated) computing magazines, just for me.

Needless to say, a great day in my life.

But with the advent of the Intertron I retreated more and more from reading paper magazine, mostly because they‚Äôre too slow. And also have horrible search facilities. Plus the links don‚Äôt work, or even worse, there are none.

Still, I read some magazines. Not many, just a very few. Mostly on the weekends, because it‚Äôs so much cooler to read while lying in a hammock, and let‚Äôs face it, a laptop in a hammock just doesn‚Äôt cut it.

So, what do I read these days?

  • S√ºddeutsche Zeitung Magazin‚Äîgreat little publication, comes with the SZ Friday issue. It may sound silly, but I really fell for that one. I consider it one of my weekly weekend highlights, because I thorougly enjoy it.
  • The Escapist‚Äîa weekly free magazine about gaming culture. Not about reviews and previews and what‚Äôs hot etc, mind you. The magazine approaches gaming on a more psychological, human, laid-back level. Each issue has a particular topic, and you can read it either on the web or print it out (beautiful PDF version!) and read it on the subway. Which I do every now and then. Quite frankly, it‚Äôs a magazine so good I would actually buy it. Or subscribe to it.
  • I stopped reading PM Magazin a short while ago, after getting it monthly for a few years. Somehow it doesn‚Äôt click with me anymore. Someone once described it to me as ‚ÄúBunte f√ºr Intellektuelle‚Äù, which I found funny, while at the same time think it‚Äôs slightly incorrect.

Well, that‚Äôs it. I toss the topic on to Hendrik, Mike, jeck, Zhaneel, Beryl and - as an experiment - the funky folks at Antigames.de. Go!

I‚Äôve used to read quite a few magazines in the day, mostly to feed my habit (PC gaming, back then); a remnant of happy times past, when I was a kid. You see, I grew up in Eastern Germany, and while I had no problems or real shortcomings there, I never really had the chance to buy computer magazines of any sort (programming, gaming etc.)‚Äîsimply because _there were none_.

Well, then one happy day, friends of my parents from Western Germany visited us, and lo and behold, they brought a few dozen (slightly outdated) computing magazines, just for me.

Needless to say, a great day in my life.

But with the advent of the Intertron I retreated more and more from reading paper magazine, mostly because they‚Äôre too slow. And also have horrible search facilities. Plus the links don‚Äôt work, or even worse, _there are none_.

Still, I read some magazines. Not many, just a very few. Mostly on the weekends, because it‚Äôs so much cooler to read while lying in a hammock, and let‚Äôs face it, a laptop in a hammock just doesn‚Äôt cut it.

So, what do I read these days?

* [S√ºddeutsche Zeitung Magazin][2]‚Äîgreat little publication, comes with the SZ Friday issue. It may sound silly, but I really fell for that one. I consider it one of my weekly weekend highlights, because I thorougly enjoy it.
* [The Escapist][3]‚Äîa weekly _free_ magazine about gaming culture. Not about reviews and previews and what‚Äôs hot etc, mind you. The magazine approaches gaming on a more psychological, human, laid-back level. Each issue has a particular topic, and you can read it either on the web or print it out (beautiful PDF version!) and read it on the subway. Which I do every now and then. Quite frankly, it‚Äôs a magazine so good I would actually buy it. Or subscribe to it.
* I stopped reading [PM Magazin][4] a short while ago, after getting it monthly for a few years. Somehow it doesn‚Äôt click with me anymore. Someone once described it to me as _‚ÄúBunte f√ºr Intellektuelle‚Äù_, which I found funny, while at the same time think it‚Äôs slightly incorrect.

Well, that‚Äôs it. I toss the topic on to [Hendrik][5], [Mike][6], [jeck][7], [Zhaneel][8], [Beryl][9] and - as an experiment - [the funky folks at Antigames.de][10]. Go!

items.title: Das Tumblringen!
items.content_html:
I‚Äôve started a tumble log the other day. I consider it an experiment; first of all, Tumblr is an exquisite service with a whole lot of potential. It serves as an extremely easy and comfortable tool to link all the new doodads, gimmicks, funny pictures and clever quotes I find on the Intertron.

And secondly, all the cool cats are doing it already, so there.

Thus, for the time being, I will do what Hendrik did and deactivate the daily automated splicing of my new del.icio.us links and blog-worthy Flickr pictures into my tail -f carlo.log RSS feed, and opt for Tumblr raking them in automatically. In addition I‚Äôll throw in the gems I found while reading feeds in Google Reader! What a deal!

That means if you want to keep track of the little things I see and find, those which do not warrant a blog post on their own here, take a look tail -f carlo.tumblr. Yes, I know the name is lame, screw you! :p There is an RSS feed, too.

So, yeah.

items.title: Mini Review: "300"
items.content_html:
Good entertainment. They‚Äôve painted some grand pictures there; I‚Äôve enjoyed the visual style. Loved the presentation; the fighting scenes with the slow/full motion switches were very well done. Featured strong women, always a plus.

Wasn‚Äôt as visionary as the hype wanted me to believe, but it has most certainly set a new high in action cinematography for me‚Äîit‚Äôs as much a visual milestone as The Matrix was back then. (Other than that you can‚Äôt compare those two flicks.)

Faramir didn‚Äôt really fit in, I think. Good performance, but his blond hair stood out a bit too much.

I still don‚Äôt think it should be called ‚Äò600‚Äô, tho.

Had the right length.

PS: I don‚Äôt feel like barking ‚ÄúThis is Sparta!‚Äù repeatedly at all. I want my money back.

items.title: Battery Hail Storm & Energy Efficiency
items.content_html:
Hail: The Return of the Sun is a well-done ad/movie for solar power. Watch it, it‚Äôs pretty cool. I saw the ad in a cinema the first time, and I found it quite good.

Staying with the topic energy & efficiency: When Dana and I moved to the new house, we made it a point to use CFL bulbs wherever possible.

Now, after taking a long, hard look at the various doodads sitting around the TV, which are burning energy in standby mode all day long, I‚Äôve decided to introduce a master/slave extension lead to the mix. So these days, when I turn off the TV, the six other machines around it (gaming consoles, sound system, DVR etc.) are completely turned off as well automatically. It‚Äôs pretty neat, albeit not perfect yet.

And according to my calculations the 25‚Ç¨ I spent on the extension lead will be paid for by the energy bill savings within less than a year.

items.content_html:
Right, I remember! Did I ever blog about being interviewed (‚Äúmentioned‚Äù would probably be the better term) by the guys over at the Yahoo Publisher Network blog? About Planet Yahoo!, of course. Hilarious how I completely forgot about this‚Ä¶

April 30. There‚Äôll be an ARG to stimulate the Collective Intelligence to deal with the idea of an oil crisis starting end of April. I must say, I love the idea. There is apparently such a huge demand for ARGs, why not use this raw potential to do something worthwhile? World Without Oil aims to do that. Kudos.

Mac game development. [via Hendrik] Game developers give the Mac another look‚Äîthis can only be a good thing. Yay!

Troubled languages. English is degrading each and every day, says Glass Maze‚Äôs lapsed cannibal in a amusing, yet angry rant.

I often find myself in meetings where the English language is beaten, burned, shat upon, drawn-and-quartered, and finally twisted into a monstrous parody of itself, then slapped onto a powerpoint slide and projected onto a wall, where its shame and ignominy are visible to all.

And you know what? He might be right, but I believe blood would come out of his ears on a daily basis, if he were a caring German listening to his native language. Don‚Äôt know what I mean? Take what he said, double it, and imagine parts of any given sentence being peppered with English/German halfbreeds constantly.

I notice that I, personally, see a decline in the quality of my German – which is my very own tongue, mind you –, due to the fact that I speak English half of the time for a good number of years by now. I switch between the languages without effort, sometimes in the middle of a sentence, and – worst of all – interchange English and German words rather frequently. Shame on me.

But the longer I think about it, the more I wonder whether this is a price we have to pay for globalization‚Ä¶ Remember Blade Runner with his ‚Äúgutter speak‚Äù? Just thinking out loud.
